questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of persistent hoarseness, throat pain, and difficulty swallowing was recently diagnosed with Laryngeal Carcinoma. Which of the following is not a known risk factor for developing laryngeal cancer in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic predisposition due to Fanconi anemia

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with progressive hoarseness of voice and mild dyspnea on exertion. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 6 months ago. A fiberoptic laryngoscopy reveals left-sided vocal cord paralysis in the paramedian position. A chest CT scan shows no mediastinal mass or aortic enlargement. Electromyography of the laryngeal muscles reveals denervation. What is the most likely cause of his vocal cord paralysis?

options.label: A
options.text: Left atrial enlargement due to mitral valve disease

options.label: B
options.text: Post-surgical trauma to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)

options.label: C
options.text: Compression of the recurrent laryngeal nerve by aortic aneurysm

questions.correct_answer: B. Post-surgical trauma to the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)
questions.explanation:
Cervical surgery
  • Thyroidectomy/parathyroidectomy
  • Carotid endarterectomy
  • Anterior approach to the cervical spine
  • Repair Zenker’s diverticulum
  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy

Thoracic procedures
  • Thoracic aneurysm repair
  • Pneumonectomy
  • Aortic valve repair
  • Coronary artery bypass grafting
  • Esophageal or tracheal surgery
  • Mediastinoscopy
  • Ligation of patent ductus arteriosus

Others
  • Skull base or brainstem surgery
  • Endotracheal intubation

questions.text: In a patient who has undergone a total laryngectomy, a portable vocal rehabilitation device needs to be prescribed immediately post-surgery. Choose the device from the given options:

In a patient diagnosed with stage 3 laryngeal carcinoma with no involvement of thyroid cartilage, the patient is unwilling to undergo chemoradiotherapy. What will be the treatment of choice in this case?

A 55-year-old patient is diagnosed with glottic carcinoma involving the right side of the vocal cord. The tumor extends to the supraglottis with impaired vocal cord mobility. What is the most appropriate primary treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
TNM Staging

Stage Grouping

Treatment

T1N0M0

Stage I

Glottic- Radiotherapy or Endoscopic CO2 laser resection

Supraglottic- Radiotherapy or Endoscopic CO2 laser resection

Subglottic- Radiotherapy

T2N0M0

Stage II

Glottic-

  • Radiotherapy- when the cord is mobile
  • Vertical hemilaryngectomy- when cord mobility is impaired or Involvement of anterior commissure/arytenoid

Supraglottic-

  • Supraglottic laryngectomy with/without neck dissection- when lung function is good
  • Supraglottic laryngectomy with/without neck dissection + Radiotherapy- when lung function is poor
 

Subglottic- Radiotherapy

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Laryngoscopy reveals a tumor involving both vocal cords with normal mobility. There is no evidence of spread beyond the larynx or lymph node involvement. Based on the TNM classification of laryngeal carcinoma, what is the most appropriate staging for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ References:

T1

Tumor is limited to one subsite of supraglottis with normal vocal cord mobility.

T2

Tumor invades mucosa of more than one adjacent subsites of supraglottis or glottis or region outside the supraglottis (e.g. mucosa of base of tongue, vallecula, medial wall of pyriform sinus) without fixation of the larynx.

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades any of the following: postcricoid area, pre-epiglottic tissues, paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage invasion.

T4a

Tumor invades through the thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

T1

Tumor limited to vocal cord(s) (may involve anterior or posterior commissures) with normal mobility.

T1a

Tumor is limited to one vocal cord. (Option A)

T1b

Tumor involves both vocal cords.

T2

Tumor extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, and/or with impaired vocal cord mobility. (Option C)

T3

Tumor is limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or minor thyroid cartilage erosion. (Option D)

T4a

Tumor invades through thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscles of the tongue, strap muscles, thyroid, or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

T1

Tumor is limited to the subglottis.

T2

Tumor extends to the vocal cord(s) with normal or impaired mobility.

T3

Tumor limited to larynx with vocal cord fixation.

T4a

Tumor invades cricoid or thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissues beyond the larynx (e.g. trachea, soft tissues of neck including deep extrinsic muscle of tongue, strap muscles, thyroid or esophagus).

T4b

Tumor invades prevertebral space, encases the carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures.

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed.

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis.

N1

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, 3 cm or less in greatest dimension.

N2

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension, or bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension.

N2a

Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node more than 3 cm but not more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2b

Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension.

N2c

Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension

Na

Metastasis in a lymph node more than 6 cm in the greatest dimension

Mx

Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0

No Distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with progressive stridor and difficulty breathing for the past 2 months. Laryngoscopy reveals a mass in the subglottic region with normal appearing and mobile vocal cords. Which of the following statements about subglottic carcinoma is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Hoarseness is typically a late symptom

options.label: B
options.text: Lymphatic spread is common to prelaryngeal and paratracheal nodes

options.label: C
options.text: It often presents with airway obstruction as an early symptom

options.label: D
options.text: Prognosis is generally better than glottic carcinoma

questions.correct_answer: D. Prognosis is generally better than glottic carcinoma
questions.explanation:
Incidence

Least common site of laryngeal cancer (1-5% of cases)

Site

Extends from undersurface of vocal cords to lower border of cricoid cartilage

Vocal cord involvement

Usually late; vocal cords often appear normal in early stages

Local Spread

Can spread circumferentially, invade cricothyroid membrane, thyroid gland, and trachea

Lymphatic spread

Common to prelaryngeal, pretracheal, paratracheal, and lower jugular nodes (Option B)

Symptoms

Early: Stridor, laryngeal obstruction (Option C)

Late: Hoarseness, cough, hemoptysis (Option A)

Histopathology

Poorly differentiated

Predominantly squamous cell carcinoma

Prognosis

Generally worse than glottic carcinoma due to late diagnosis and higher rate of lymph node metastasis

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with persistent hoarseness for the past 2 months. Laryngoscopy reveals a small lesion on the anterior third of the right vocal cord with normal cord mobility. Further investigations lead to the diagnosis of Glottic laryngeal carcinoma. Which of the following statements about the condition is incorrect ?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the most common site of origin for glottic carcinoma

options.label: B
options.text: Hoarseness is typically an early symptom

options.label: C
options.text: Lymph node metastases are common in early stages

options.label: D
options.text: Histopathologically well differentiated and less malignant

questions.correct_answer: C. Lymph node metastases are common in early stages
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ References:

Incidence
  • Most common site of laryngeal cancer origin (Option A)

Site
  • Free edge and upper surface of vocal cord, mainly in anterior and middle third

Vocal cord involvement
  • Involvement of vocal cord occurs early so the patient presents early with hoarseness of voice (Option B)
  • Vocal cord fixation indicates spread to thyroarytenoid muscle and is a bad prognostic sign

Lymphatic spread
  • Rare due to few lymphatics in vocal cords

Local Spread
  • Can spread locally to anterior commissure, opposite cord, arytenoid region, ventricle, false cord, and subglottic region

Symptoms
  • Hoarseness is an early sign; stridor and laryngeal obstruction in advanced cases

Histopathology
  • Well differentiated and less malignant (Option D)

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with dysphagia, throat pain, and a palpable neck mass. Laryngoscopy reveals a lesion on the epiglottis. Further investigations lead to the diagnosis of Laryngeal carcinoma.Which of the following is not a typical characteristic of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late

options.label: B
options.text: Hoarseness is usually a late symptom

options.label: C
options.text: The most common histological type is squamous cell carcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: It may spread to the pre-epiglottic space

questions.correct_answer: A. Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late
questions.explanation:
Incidence

Less frequent than glottic cancer; about 30-35% of all laryngeal cancers

Site

Majority on epiglottis, false cords, followed by aryepiglottic folds

Vocal cord involvement

Usually late; vocal cords often spared in early stages

Lymphatic spread
  • Early and often bilateral
  • Upper and middle jugular nodes commonly involved
  • Cancer of infrahyoid epiglottis & anterior ventricular band may extend into pre-epiglottic space (Option D)

Symptoms
  • Early: Often silent, dysphagia, throat pain
  • Late: Hoarseness, weight loss, respiratory obstruction, halitosis (Option B)

Histopathology
  • 90-95% squamous cell carcinoma (Option C)
  • Others include verrucous carcinoma, spindle cell carcinoma
  • Highly anaplastic

Prognosis

Generally worse than glottic cancer due to:

  • Late diagnosis
  • High rate & early lymph node metastasis
  • Anaplastic nature

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the laryngeal nerve supply is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The right recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the vagus at the level of the subclavian artery, while the left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises at the level of the arch of the aorta.

options.label: B
options.text: The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal cords.

options.label: C
options.text: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve innervates the cricothyroid muscle.

options.label: D
options.text: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a longer course than the right, making it more prone to paralysis.

questions.correct_answer: B. The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal cords.

questions.text: During a thyroidectomy, the surgeon encounters difficulty identifying the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN). To improve nerve visualization, the surgeon decides to explore a specific avascular space between the upper pole of the thyroid gland and the cricothyroid muscle. Which of the following spaces is the surgeon aiming to open to aid in the preservation of the EBSLN?
Joll’s Triangle is used to identify which of the following nerves?

options.label: B
options.text: External Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve

options.label: C
options.text: Internal Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve

questions.correct_answer: B. External Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following triangles is not used to identify the recurrent laryngeal nerve?
questions.explanation:
RLN identification triangles

Description

Beahrs Triangle (Riddle’s Triangle) (Option C)

 

  • Boundaries:
    • Common carotid artery (base)
    • Inferior thyroid artery (superior)
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve (third side)
  • Location: Posterior to thyroid gland in the tracheoesophageal groove.
  • Importance: Used to safeguard the recurrent laryngeal nerve during thyroid surgery

Simon’s Triangle (Option A)


 
  • Boundaries:
    • Common carotid artery (lateral)
    • Esophagus (medial)
    • Inferior thyroid artery (superior)
  • Importance: RLN crosses the triangle and is identified intraoperatively.

Lore’s Triangle (Option D)


 
  • Boundaries:
    • Trachea/esophagus (medial)
    • Common carotid artery (lateral)
    • Surface of the inferior pole of thyroid (superior)
  • Importance: Used for identification of the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) Triangle
  • Boundaries:
    • Apex: Thoracic inlet (inferior)
    • Medial: Trachea
    • Lateral: Medial edge of retracted strap muscles
    • Superior: Lower edge of inferior thyroid pole
  • Importance: RLN exits as a single trunk at the thoracic inlet.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male underwent total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goiter. Postoperatively, he presents with complete loss of voice, frequent aspiration of liquids, and an inability to cough effectively. On laryngoscopy, both vocal cords are found in a cadaveric position, and there is no sensation in the larynx. He is also experiencing difficulty breathing and frequent episodes of bronchopneumonia. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Unilateral recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Bilateral recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis

questions.correct_answer: D. Bilateral recurrent and superior laryngeal nerve paralysis
questions.explanation:
Feature

Unilateral Combined Paralysis

Bilateral Combined Paralysis

Affected Nerves
  • One side (Recurrent and Superior Laryngeal Nerves)
  • Thyroid surgery is the most common cause.
  • Both sides (Recurrent and Superior Laryngeal Nerves)

Vocal Cord Position
  • Paralyzed cord in cadaveric position (3.5 mm from midline)
  • Healthy cord unable to fully approximate paralyzed cord
  • Both cords in the cadaveric (Intermediate) position (neutral, apart from midline)
  • Complete lack of movement in both cords

Clinical Features
  • All the muscles of the larynx on one side are paralyzed except the interarytenoid.
  • Hoarseness: Due to glottic incompetence
  • Aspiration: Liquids pass through the glottis
  • Ineffective cough: Due to air waste from incomplete vocal fold closure
  • Mild aspiration risk
  • Breathing: Usually unaffected as airway remains adequate
  • Speech: Weak or breathy, but functional
  • All the laryngeal muscles are paralyzed.
  • Total anesthesia of the larynx.
  • Aphonia: Complete loss of voice as cords do not meet
  • Severe aspiration: Total glottic incompetence, laryngeal anesthesia
  • Inability to cough: Cords cannot meet to generate pressure for coughing
  • Bronchopneumonia: Due to frequent aspiration of secretions into the lungs
  • Respiratory distress: Due to compromised airway and retention of secretions
  • Speech: Completely absent

Treatment
  • Voice therapy - for compensation by the healthy cord
  • Injection laryngoplasty (temporary or permanent fillers)
  • Thyroplasty Type I with or without arytenoid adduction
  • Tracheostomy to clear pulmonary secretions
  • Gastrostomy to prevent aspiration and maintain nutrition
  • Epiglottopexy to prevent aspiration
  • Vocal cord plication to prevent aspiration
  • Total laryngectomy or diversion procedures in severe cases

questions.text: A 45-year-old professional singer presents with complaints of vocal fatigue and difficulty producing high-pitched sounds for the last 3 months. She denies any difficulty in swallowing or breathing. On laryngoscopic examination, no significant abnormalities are seen, and one vocal cord appears to be in normal resting position while other vocal cord is in abducted position . What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old female presents with hoarseness , shortness of breath and stridor following thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral vocal cord paralysis with both cords fixed in paramedian position. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management?

A 45-year-old male patient presents with hoarseness of voice following a thyroidectomy. On laryngoscopic examination, his vocal cord is found to be in the paramedian position. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: D
options.text: Paralysis of both RLN and SLN

questions.correct_answer: B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) paralysis
questions.explanation:
Position of Vocal Cords

Healthy State

Diseased State

Phonation

RLN paralysis

1.5 mm

Strong whisper

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is primarily responsible for adducting the vocal folds and closing the rima glottidis during phonation?
